bibl.title: Letter fragment to Florence M. Read, June 9, 1921

div1.p: This letter concerns qualifications of yellow fever workers.

div1.head: Letter fragment to Florence M. Read, June 9, 1921
div1.opener:
R
Report Report
Hanson (Hav)
Peru
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
June 9, 1921.
Dear Miss Read:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of June 7th. I would say that you
had best retain the original letters concerning Parker: Gage:
Hayne and Carter, transmitted in my letter of June 4th., as they
contain data enabling Dr. Rose to judge of the qualifications of
these men; maybe for future use,

With regard to Dr. Hanson's letter I would say that he is
acting wisely in placing Pickett and Corrigan in Trujillo to pro-
tect the District threatened with yellow fever rather than to
work for its elimination where it is well established. This is
in accordance with the plans outlined before I left Peru.

So for his other assignments: Mendoza: Caballero: Quiroz:
Vega and Zapata are the best medical men at his dispocion, and about
in this order. The last two must stay to protect the important
points in the Province of Piura and the first two are very proper-
ly brought down into the Provinces of Pacasmayo and Trujillo; Qui-
roz was in charge of Lambayeque. I presume the “Dr. Ricardo,”
whom you state has the Province of Pacasmayo, is Ricardo Mendoza,
